required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Home-Based Dual-Task Training for Older Adults
clinical_study.official_title: Home-Based Dual-Task Training to Improve Function in Older Adults

lead_sponsor.agency: State University of New York at Buffalo

clinical_study.source: State University of New York at Buffalo

brief_summary.textblock: This project is focused on conducting a home-based, thinking while moving exercise intervention for adults 65 years or older, who have mild cognitive impairment, that will integrate several effective training modalities including non-contact cardio-kickboxing, stepping exercise, balance/functional training, and muscle strengthening. Cognitive function, physical function, and dual-task abilities will be assessed over the 12-week intervention and comparisons will be made between participants in the exercise intervention and control participants receiving no intervention.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Cognitive Function (Interference inhibition and attention)
primary_outcome.description: Change in performance on the Stroop Color-Word Interference Test

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Cognitive Function (Task-switching and attention)
primary_outcome.description: Change in performance on the Trail-Making Test Sections A and B

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Walking Ability, Lower-Body Strength, and Balance
primary_outcome.description: Change in performance on the Short Physical Performance Battery

secondary_outcome.description: Change in the Timed Up and Go Test: Dual Task (single condition, motor condition, and cognitive condition

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 65 years or older
- Male or female
- Screened positive for mild cognitive impairment (Montreal Cognitive Assessment score 23 to 26 points
- Having no absolute contraindications to non-physician supervised exercise.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Lower-body amputation
- Non-English language speaker

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: State University of New York at Buffalo
